reviewText:
Surprisingly tense and atmospheric stealth FPS with a quirky sense of humour, sort of like an indie Deus Ex. Hostiles hit hard, discouraging direct fire fights, but giving them a real sense of urgency when they do break out. The stealth *is* a little wonky but works overall. Mostly because toggling between sneak / running / crouch feels a bit clumsy and can scupper you in moments of confusion. Aside from this I've definitely been having fun so far.

At the time of writing I'm about half way through the level select, on the 5th out of 10 levels, following an hour of play. I guess the game could be quite short if it continues at this pace, maybe 2-3 hours. However the game makes a significant jump in difficulty during level 5, so it may be longer than this. The difficulty shift is accompanied by a slight shift in tone too, one that is both strangely fitting and a little creepy. I'm curious to see where it goes. It also makes me think that the developer got hooked on Dark Souls half way through development, which is no bad thing. I'm not saying it is like Dark Souls though, just a few aspects make me think of the game.

Comments on the Steam Hub suggest it will be $8 at launch. I would recommend it at that price, though the possible short length may be something you should consider before buying.

Note: This is a pre-release review written via a Steam key obtained the developer. I originally purchased the game in very early alpha in June 2014 and asked for a Steam key when I saw it was releasing on Steam. I was not asked to review the game.

reviewText:
I AM PERFECTLY WILLING TO COME BACK TO THIS GAME ON EVERY UPDATE AND CHANGE MY REVIEWS WHEN PROGRESS IS MADE ON THESE ISSUES. I really want to love this game, and this is just temporary constructive criticism

At the moment, ROOT has a few incredibly frustrating niggles that get in the way of me enjoying its stealth mechanics:

1) THE RANGE!!! Attacks have a range that feels completely inconsistent and forces me to basically grind against any targets that I want to hit. Sometimes even when hugging an enemy my attacks don't connect. If an enemy is aiming at me then my kicks won't connect unless I am aiming at his arms because his chest is too far away even if my hitbox is literally colliding with his. This is very frustrating because it makes me battle with the inconsistency of my moves as much as the guards and levels.

2) The hitboxes feel inconsistent. Headshots count for nothing, and sometimes stealth kills don't register if they are a few pixels below the designated neck point, which happens to be higher the characters camera. These are minor gripes.

3) Sometimes it's simply impossible to know what you are walking into when you cross a door, and the sides of the door are not adaquate for hiding. Sometimes I'll open a door and the guard will be at a point in their patrol where they will see me instantly even if I'm hiding on the side of the door they're coming from. imo the challenge of the game shouldn't come from dangers like this that feel so arbitrary and removed from skill.

4) Limited mechanics for stealth. It feels like stealth doesn't have a ton of width in this game, the main stealth mechanic is basically just positioning.

What I do like:

1) The enviroments get  pretty interesting for stealth.

2) Knocking a guard out makes a very satisfying thwack with a great ragdoll thump. Don't underestimate the importance of that.

reviewText:
ROOT is a stealth action, first person shooter that allows you to crawl though air ducts and sneak around to devastate the security of the system you are infiltrating, or you can go guns blazing. With many enemy types that respond to your intrusion differently, it is certainly a game to take a look at!

In all seriousness though, the multiple paths allowed to be taken with the stealth aspect make this quite an enjoyable ride for a decent amount of time. Could be tough for some, but take it as a challenge rather than otherwise! The artistic style appears simplistic, but you can change the colors of some things to your preference. This design choice also fits the mood of the game.

I will attach the preview video for those that understand a bit better via picture/video. I liked the game, and recommend that anyone take a look around to see if you might like it!


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ks4jtolEiVE

reviewText:
I like the game, but took it slow due to my preference for stealth and the frustration choosing to go that route causes.

Graphics 5/5
These are clean and neat looking. I find that they come across as unique in modern times. The animations are smooth. *See options menu

Music4/5
The music is suitable for the game. It feels right. Nothing stellar there, but it's good enough.

Options Menu 5/5
The options menu is REALLY well made. The controls are simple but can all be changed here. Most interestingly, the option to change the color scheme of the graphics is included. This is a normally overlooked aspect of the options menu that should help those that suffer certain color blindnesses. Good audio controls.

Gameplay 4/5
The actual gameplay feels alright. Some kind of cross between FPS and Stealth. Shooting plays a larger part than the stealth, due to how difficult clubbing moving targets is. If you try to stealth the whole game, it will be incredibly frustrating at times. Level design is weird, but that should be intentional here. The AI could be smarter, but is probably at the appropriate intelligence considering the stealthing difficulties.

There is a story. It's alright. I don't think it's the emphasize of this game.

Price
The cost is fine for the length/quality of game. At the very least, worth it on sale.

Overall, it looks nice and sounds good. If you are looking for a simple but not easy FPS, this is a good game. If you are looking for a HARD stealth game, this is a good game. Some aspects of the stealth feel off, but you can work around those.

I believe this is the first game by this developer. Its a good start.

reviewText:
Nice little stealth game with vr mission graphics and some sci-fi Deus Ex style elements (ie: vents).

So far the gameplay (sneaking, weapons-gun/club, enemy AI, peeking around walls) has been good, wish it had gamepad support though. The enemies start off moving painfully slow during patrols so plan to wait often. The neon-colored transparent objects give you a way to see them while bing covert. Nice simple graphics and music.

8.5/10 for the price

Add gamepad support please.

reviewText: ROOT is a fun and (very) challenging FPS unlike any you've ever played. The biggest thing to remember is that ROOT is neither run 'n gun, or stealth. Rather it is a mixture of both, and you cannot succeed by doing just one or the other. The key in ROOT is to strategize your moves. Think, then act. Don't act, then think. That, and commit to your actions. If you make the choice to enter and clear a room, commit to that choice and don't half-♥♥♥ it. Those are my tips for you.\n\nROOT is definitely a unique game. For one thing, the game takes place inside of a computer system as you, Edward Summerton" (creative name
recommended: attempt to hack your way in. Data and security software is manifested as objects and enemies
voteText: objects are shaded in as colors which you can customize entirely to your liking.\n\nThere are three weapons in ROOT. A nightstick
helpfulPercent: which can be used to silently subdue enemies from behind. A pistol
votesHelpful: which is accurate at all ranges but does low damage. And a shotgun
votesTotal: which is (obviously) best at close range but does high damage. Weapon handling is different from most shooters in that there is no recoil
column16: and your shots are placed exactly where you put the cursor. This makes your ability to aim of absolute importance
column17: as you can't simply panic-fire and count on spread to make some of your shots  hit the target.\n\nThis is a game that forces the player to tread softly if they want to survive. Nearly all of the enemies you will face are stronger than you and you must be on the alert
column18: constantly scanning for threats. It is
column20: not difficult to hide from these enemies if you memorize their patterns and know what to do. Most of the AIs are exceedingly stupid
column21: and can be thwarted so long as you remain calm and take things slow.\n\nOverall
column22: ROOT is a very fun game that I reccomend to anyone looking for a change of pace in an FPS game. Although bare in mind that it is a frustrating game; you will likely die... a lot. The end boss is especially difficult
column23: but he can be beaten if you persevere. I definitely encourage you to give this one a try
column24: especially if you are bored with the run-of-the-mill shooters

reviewText:
While Root really wasn't for me I think people who like more traditional first person shooters will enjoy the game quite a bit more than me.

I really can't put my finger on why I didn't really like Root. The gameplay is fine, the atmosphere/story is interesting and I didn't mind the difficulty. For some reason the game just didn't appeal to me. This doesn't mean that Root is a bad game since I think a lot of people will enjoy the game.

While the game advertises itself as a stealth game I agree with some of the other reviewers that say the game is more of a FPS than a stealth game. If you play the game as a stealth game it is kind of boring. I started playing the game as a stealth game and when I switched to playing it as a FPS I had considerably more fun with the game.

Overall the game is pretty difficult. You really can't run and gun in the game since you will die quickly. You need to take your time and make good use of cover.

If you are looking for a hard first person shooter I think you will enjoy Root even if the game didn't really appeal to me.

Note: I received a review copy of the game from the developer.

Read My Full Review [www.geekyhobbies.com]
